title.narrative: Discovered India Activation Approach – supporting Indian Artisans to help grow their businesses

description.narrative: The Indian artisan handicraft industry is the second largest source of employment in India and a major source of income for rural communities. Official reports estimate approximately 14 million Indians are engaged with craft production. Unofficial sources estimate 200 million artisans depend on their crafts for livelihood. A majority of the people working in the sector are woman and people belonging to minority groups and ‘weaker’ parts of the Indian society. Even though the industry has high potential, it’s not fully utilised yet and local artisans are often trapped in their local economies and rely on middlemen to sell more, leaving them with very little of the proceeds and no easy access to growth capital. The Dutch company Discovered B.V. is on a mission to empower global artisans to use ‘business as a force of good’ by providing easy access to international buyer markets. The Discovered platform allows artisans to sell more products at better price, increase their income with 25% and enhance their access to funding. In order to prepare for future investments and to create immediate impact for local artisan businesses, Technical Assistance (DGGF) provided support to validate the scalability and replication ability of the Discovered Artisan Activation Approach. The project included the assessment of key challenges artisan led businesses face, providing artisans with skills development, training and workshops to overcome these challenges and help the micro-enterprises grow into sustainable businesses by opening their own online and international shops through Discovered’s platform. The Technical Assistance Discovered resulted in the opening of 1 regional activation HUB for local artisans in Bangalore, partnerships with 3 specialised NGOSs and the opening of 300, mostly female led, artisan online stores that represent 25,000 artisans and through which over 7,5000 unique products have already been sold. Furthermore, the project supported 7 direct jobs and enabled knowledge transfer and skills development of more than 300 people regarding managing online stores and international sales. The project has been successful and Discovered is currently preparing to further scale-up its activities in India by partnering up with 10 NGOs through which an additional 50,000 artisans will be reached and will have an immediate positive impact on their livelihoods.
